183564595.review:
Don't let the gameplay fool you, the main story sucks!

God where to start? The villains suck. Scarecrow was so cool in Asylum with his mind bending sections but here he is the blandest villain who wants to bore Batman to death with some of the most generic villain monologues you will ever hear in your life while he hide behind a screen and cover the city in his fart cloud because why make him sinister or compelling like any other Batman villain when you can turn him into Dr Evil without the self-awareness. Really, is this the best you can do with him?

While I'm on the topic of bad villains, the Arkham Knight is the worst batman villain ever made. All he does is whine like a spoiled child and not killing Batman even though he constantly whines about wanting to kill him. for example there is a scene where he gets on top of Batman and puts a bullet in him but he just out of nowhere walks away for no reason and another seen where he has Batman at gun point and he just whines like he always does and doesn't start shooting until after he gets away. He is literally Kai Leng from Mass Effect 3 but at least Kai Leng is funny-bad while the Arkham Knight is just frustrating because the worst part about him is the fact that he's Jason Todd. One, not only its a VERY predictable twist even to those who don't know about Batman lore because half-way through the game it slaps you in the face with it and I don't want hear any one say "Um actually it's supposed to be predictable" because if you play the game on PS4 it turns off your clip recording at the big reveal scene. Two, his character is butchered hard. In the comics and the Under The Red Hood movie he is a cool representation of the flaws of Batman's philosophy but here he's just a generic enforcer character. I don't find his backstory tragic because it comes out of nowhere and he wasn't mentioned once in the last two games like a worse Sam Drake and it relies on the characters being stupid because your meaning to tell me the worlds greatest detective assumed Jason was dead just because Joker showed him a video? By that logic he must think that fake AI movie trailers are real.

Speaking of Batman, he is such a ***hole to his close allies just for the sake of cheep drama. He locks Robin in a cell and feels no remorse about it while also giving him a terrible haircut. His intelligence has also been giving a massive downgrade for example he can't tell that it's Jason who's the Arkham Knight even though hes not doing a good job hiding his voice and Batman's first batch of suspects are a bunch of no-name goons from Arkham Asylum/City. There is also a scene where he has Scarecrow in his grasp but instead of restraining him or knocking him out he tells the person IN A WHEELCHAIR to run leaving Scarecrow to escape ****ing pathetic writing. Lastly another scene where he gets faced-timed by worse Kai Leng and he threatens one of his henchmen to tell him his location even though it doesn't take "the worlds greatest detective" to tell the neon sign behind him says iceberg as in The Penguin's Iceberg Lounge, its the same font as it was in Arkham City. He only threatens him just to tell the players that he's Violently Determined on finding Barbara when it could have just be moved to the airship section or not have the face-time. He also so emotionless most of the time like hes the T-800 which make it hard to connect to him when I know the character of Batman is capable of so much more. I also don't want to hear "Um actually he's like that because of Talia's death" because Talia had only 5 minutes of screen time and she had no definable traits other than "notice me Batman" so it's hard for me to care. Even Kevin Conroy's performance sounds flat like he knows how bad the writing is or it's bad voice direction. He does a better job as Hush in this game and I will get to Hush don't you worry. I also feel that Jonathan Banks is also wasted as Jim Gordon. He sound bored through out the game when I know he can do better than this, just go and watch Better Call Saul.

Now let's get into the wasted potential of Hush. The last game had a whole side mission dedicated to setting up his role in this game and all it amounts to is a ****ing David Cage QTE. Why not make Hush the Arkham Knight considering that he's already a better villain because he doesn't whine like a little baby and I don't care if you think he suck because you got that opinion from some guy on Reddit he deserves more screen time than Poison Ivy.

Her "redemption arc" comes out of nowhere because it wasn't foreshadowed in the past games at all. She never valued human life and only valued plant life and she only agrees to help Batman because of her plants so when she "dies" I feel nothing because it doesn't feel earned. Alfred says that there was "goodness in her" but her "death" doesn't feel earned, it doesn't say anything about her morality, she dies the same cold-hearted b**** she always been. It's nothing more than another cheep attempt at drama. I mean it when I say I felt more when Frank Boles died. Also the game heavily implies that shes still alive, it's one of the riddles you have to scan. But hey maybe the game could have fleshed her out if all the screen-time wasn't given to Mr Over Saturation aka The Joker. 

He comes back like Palatine in Rise Of Skywalker only to be unfunny comic relief, quipping jokes that appeal to people who watch Family Guy. The screen time he had in the last two game was digestible but in this game he has too much screen time I wanted him gone early into this game. The way he does come back doesn't make sense and is very convoluted that I would even bother trying to describe it and every "explanation" I heard relies so much on head-cannoning it makes my head hurt. I also ****ing hate the Joker infected both as characters and as concepts. Their existence devalues The Joker as a character if he can copied that easily and don't give me that one bad day bull**** because if you actually read The Killing Joke The Joker was wrong about that. 183515754.review:
Batman Arkham Night foi meu primeiro contato com a série Batman e, sinceramente, não poderia ter sido um começo melhor. A qualidade gráfica, considerando o ano de lançamento, é excelente e a jogabilidade é fluida e viciante. A história é ótima e os diálogos são muito bem escritos. A dublagem brasileira, como sempre, coloca a experiência em outro nível. 

Comparado a outros jogos que já joguei – lançados muitos depois deste -, Batman Arkham Night se destaca pela atenção aos detalhes e pela imersão que proporciona. 
Apesar de algumas referências a jogos anteriores, não tive maiores dificuldades em entender o contexto da história, no entanto, jogar – ou minimamente saber sobre os acontecimentos que ocorrem nos games anteriores - torna a experiência ainda melhor. 

Com 30 horas de jogo, concluí a história principal e parte das missões secundárias, mas ainda há muito o que fazer: desafios, eventos aleatórios e missões menores espalhadas pela cidade. A dificuldade é bem equilibrada, exige certo nível de habilidade e até planejamento, mas nada extremo. As ferramentas são extremamente úteis durante todo o game, nada está ali atoa. E por falar em coisa útil, devo dizer, uma das melhores coisas desse game é o combate com o carro, apenas jogue. 

Embora alguns eventos, como destruir torres de observação e liberar pontos de controle, se repitam, a quantidade é pequena e não atrapalha o andamento da história. A variedade de missões compensa. 
Comprei a versão Premium por R$27 e recomendo esperar uma promoção para quem ainda não jogou. Apesar de ter gostado bastante e, até o momento não ter percebido ou experimentado tanta coisa negativa, recomendo esperar uma promoção. 

Em síntese, um excelente jogo. 

Até breve :)
